channel.title: The Context #androiddev
channel.itunes:author: Artem Zinnatullin
channel.itunes:subtitle: New Android Developers Podcast
channel.itunes:summary: The Context is a podcast about Android Development

item.title: Episode 1, Architecture of modern Android apps with Hannes Dorfmann
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 1: Architecture of modern Android apps

In this episode we have talked about software architecture on Android. We have covered:

  • MVC
  • MVVM
  • MVVMC
  • MVP
  • Flux
  • Cycle.js (a.k.a. Model-View-Intent)

Guest:

Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub

Open Source projects from Hannes:

  • Mosby
  • SQLBrite-DAO
  • FragmentArgs
  • ParcelablePlease

Additional links

  • AutoValue split into 2 jars issue
  • Dagger 2 document about testing
  • Clean MVVM example
  • Gradle's incremental build issue with annotation processing

item.title: Episode 2, Testing with Mike Evans
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 2: Testing

In this episode we have talked about testing in Android Development. We have covered:

  • Unit testing
  • Integration testing
  • Functional (UI) testing
  • Robolectric
  • Android Instrumentation API
  • UI Automator
  • Espresso
  • Robotium
  • Appium
  • JUnit
  • AssertJ
  • Thruth
  • Spock
  • Spek
  • Questions asked by listeners.

Host:

Artem Zinnatullin @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub

Guest:

Mike Evans @m_evans10, personal blog, GitHub

Open Source projects from Mike:

  • Aftermath
  • ColorArt

Additional links:

  • #qualitymatters
  • U2020
  • Android Needs A Simulator, Not An Emulator

item.title: Episode 3, Part 1: RxJava with its core developer David Karnok
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 3, Part 1: RxJava with its core developer David Karnok

  • Discussion before the episode
  • Discussion after the episode

In this part of the episode we have talked about RxJava. We have covered:

  • Past of RxJava
  • Background of David Karnok and his earlier implementation of Reactive Extensions for JVM
  • Current state of the RxJava development
  • Reactive Streams specification
  • JDK 9 Flow API
  • RxJava v2 and Android compatibility

Host:

Artem Zinnatullin @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub

Guest:

David Karnok @akarnokd, personal blog, GitHub

item.title: Episode 3, Part 2: RxJava tech details with its core developer David Karnok
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 3, Part 2: RxJava tech details with its core developer David Karnok

  • Discussion before the episode
  • Discussion after the episode

More technical questions about RxJava. We have covered:

  • Schedulers.computation() in RxJava
  • Schedulers in RxJava
  • subscribeOn() and observeOn()
  • Testing code with RxJava
  • Extending the Observable

Guest:

David Karnok @akarnokd, personal blog, GitHub

Host:

Artem Zinnatullin @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub

item.title: Episode 4: Indie Development with Chris Lacy
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 4: Indie Development

  • Discussion after the episode

In this episode we have talked about Indie Development. We have covered:

  • How to get started in Indie development
  • Project management as single developer
  • Testing and Continuous Integration
  • How does an Indie developer decides which libraries or technologies to use?
  • Designing without being a designer
  • Play Store, in app purchases and subscriptions

Guest:

Chris Lacy @chrismlacy

Apps published by Chris Lacy on Google Play Store:

  • Action Launcher 3
  • Action Launcher 2
  • Tweet Lanes

Hosts:

  • Artem Zinnatullin @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub
  • Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub

Additional links:

  • The Blerg: Chris Lacy's podcast
  • Chris blog post about selling Link Bubble
  • Link Bubble has been open sourced

item.itunes:summary:
Episode 5: Android TV

item.title: Episode 7: React Native with Felipe Lima from Airbnb
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 7: React Native with Felipe Lima from Airbnb

How to listen & subscribe

  • Discussion after the episode

In this episode we have talked with Felipe Lima about React Native, a cross platform solution to build native mobile apps using JavaScript and React, and how React Native is used at Airbnb. We have covered:

  • Advantages and Disadvantages of React Native
  • React Native build tools, IDE and debugging
  • How to write your own custom component
  • Lifecycle, state restoration and process death in React Native apps
  • Integration and interaction with android system services
  • Sharing code with iOS
  • Usage for React Native in Airbnb's android and iOS app

Guest:

Felipe Lima @felipecsl, personal blog, personal website, GitHub

Hosts:

  • Artem Zinnatullin @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub
  • Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub

Additional links:

  • React Native website
  • Thoughts on React Native by Felipe sample on github
  • ReactiveConf 2016 (YouTube) - Bridging the Gap: How to use React Native in existing large native code bases by Airbnb engineer Leland Richardson.

item.title: Episode 8: Damn Functional Programming with Paco Estevez
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 8: Damn Functional Programming with Paco Estevez

How to listen & subscribe

  • Discussion after the episode

In this episode we have talked with Paco Estevez about Functional Programming and how he applies Functional Programming in his android apps. We have covered:

  • Concepts of Functional Programming
  • Monads, Pure Functions, Immutability, Tuples, Union Types
  • Pattern Matching
  • Error Handling
  • Functional Reactive Programming with RxJava
  • Restoring state in Android apps

Guest:

Paco Estevez @pacoworks, personal blog, GitHub

Hosts:

  • Artem Zinnatullin @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub
  • Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub

Additional links:

Talks, books and websites about Functional Programming:

  • Clojure for the Brave and True
  • Learn You a Haskell for Great Good
  • F# for fun and profit
  • Talk by Paco about Memory Management in Fully Reactive Apps

Some of Paco's open source libraries:

  • Komprehensions
  • RxSealedUnions
  • RxTuples

item.title: Episode 9, Part 1: Kotlin Gradle plugin, compilers and build systems with Alexey Tsvetkov
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 9, Part 1: Kotlin Gradle plugin, compilers and build systems with Alexey Tsvetkov

Important note for Pocket Casts app users: Unfortunately Pocket Casts android app has a problem with downloading our episodes (to listen to them offline). It seems that while downloading their android app is using a old http client which doesn't support latest TLS cipher standards we use on server side to host our episodes.

Nevertheless, streaming our episodes (instead of downloading) works in Pocket Casts android app.

See this tutorial: Pocket Casts: Streaming

How to listen & subscribe

  • Discussion after the episode

In this episode we have talked with Alexey Tsvetkov who works at the Kotlin team at jetbrains on Kotlin's gradle plugin, compilers and build systems in general.

In the first part (of two parts) we have covered:

  • Gradle Build System and its build phases
  • Kotlin Gradle plugin
  • Compiling mixed Kotlin and Java projects
  • Incremental compilation
  • How a compiler works
  • Compiler Frontends and Backends

Guest:

Alexey Tsvetkov @tsvtkv, GitHub

Hosts:

  • Artem Zinnatullin @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub
  • Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub

Additional links:

  • Kotlin programming language
  • Gradle: The Build Lifecycle
  • Kotlin native
  • JPS: IntelliJ IDEA's internal build system
  • Kotlin Koans

item.itunes:summary:
Episode 9, Part 2: Gradle, Buck and Bazel with Alexey Tsvetkov

Important note for Pocket Casts app users: Thanks to the great support of Pocket Casts team we were able to fix the "download episodes issue" (see show nodes of episode 9, part 1).

  • Fragmented Podcast, Episode 68: Talking Buck with Uber engineer Gautam Korlam

item.title: Episode 10: Kotlin Language Design Nitpicking with Dmitry Jemerov from JetBrains
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 10: Kotlin Language Design Nitpicking with Dmitry Jemerov from JetBrains

We know about sound volume level issue #67 and tried our best to maximize it in this episode, but Artem used his crappy headphones mic instead of professional one and we couldn't achieve what we wanted, sorry about that, we'll try our best in next episode.

How to listen & subscribe

  • Discussion after the episode

We've talked to Dmitry Jemerov aka @yole from Kotlin team at JetBrains about some language design decisions made in Kotlin:

  • Package visibility in Kotlin
  • Java static equivalent in Kotlin
  • Companion objects
  • Static extension functions
  • Classes are final by default but fields are public
  • Unchecked exceptions
  • Generics
  • Base types: Any, Unit, Nothing
  • Traits
  • Delegates
  • Data classes
  • Upcoming features

Guest:

Dmitry Jemerov @intelliyole, personal blog, GitHub

Hosts:

  • Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub
  • Artem Zinnatullin @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub

Additional links:

  • Book: Kotlin in Action written by Dmitry Jemerov and Svetlana Isakova
  • Official Kotlin website with photo of lighthouse on Kotlin island

item.title: Episode 11: Migration to RxJava 2 with Artur Dryomov from Juno
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 11: Migration to RxJava 2 with Artur Dryomov from Juno

How to listen & subscribe

  • Discussion after the episode

We've talked to Artur about Juno's way to migrate their Android Riders App from RxJava 1 to RxJava 2. We have covered:

  • Migration strategy at Juno
  • What's different in RxJava 2.0?
  • Null values in RxJava 2
  • Flowable or Observable?
  • Other Rx Types: Single, Maybe and Completable
  • RxJava 2 interop library
  • RxJava 2: Default UncaughtExceptionHandler logs exceptions silently in JVM unit tests
  • RxJava 3

Guest:

  • Artur Dryomov GitHub

Hosts:

  • Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub
  • Artem Zinnatullin @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub

Additional links:

  • Juno's Android Rider Team RxJava 2 Migration Specification
  • RxKotlin
  • RxJava 2 interop library
  • What's different in RxJava 2.0
  • RxJava 2: Which type to use
  • RxJava 2: Uncaught errors fail silently in junit tests
  • RxJava 2: Discussion about null values
  • Reactive Streams specification: null value
  • RxJava 2 Kotlin SAM issue combineLatest()/etc
  • Why RxJava 3: Split the library into two or adding types for symmetry
  • RxJava 3 Preview

item.title: Episode 12: Instant Apps with Lukas Olsen and Christian Bahl

We apologize for the bad sound quality and low sound volume.

Hannes chatted with his coworkes Lukas and Christian about Instant Apps. Unfortunately, Artem wasn't able to join us for this episode. We have covered:

  • How Instant Apps work
  • Limitations
  • Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP)
  • Gradle Plugins: com.android.instantapp and com.android.feature
  • Sharing code between regular App and Instant App
  • User Experience with Instant Apps

    • Life is Great and Everything Will Be Ok, Kotlin is Here
    • Architecture Components
    • Speeding Up Your Android Gradle Builds
    • Introduction to Android Instant Apps

item.title: Episode 13: Conductor with Eric Kuck
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 13: Conductor with Eric Kuck

How to listen & subscribe

  • Discussion after the episode

Announcement: We have a new Co-Host for our podcast: Welcome Artur Dryomov!

We think that we need at least two hosts on each episode to produce a high-quality content. Unfortunately, podcast production is time-consuming but now there are three hosts, so we can ensure that at least two of us have time to produce a new episode regularly.

In this episode Artur and Hannes chatted with Eric Kuck about Conductor, a framework created by Eric as alternative to Fragments. We discussed:

  • Motivation behind Conductor
  • Conductor components: Controller, Router, ChangeHandler and ControllerTransaction
  • How Conductor works behind the scenes
  • Single Activity Applications
  • Testing
  • The future of Conductor

Guest:

  • Eric Kuck @eric_kuck, GitHub

Hosts:

  • Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub
  • Artur Dryomov @arturdryomov, GitHub

Additional links:

  • Conductor on GitHub
  • Demo of Glide integration with Controller LifecycleListener

item.title: Episode 15: 2017 in Retrospective
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 15: 2017 in Retrospective

How to listen & subscribe

  • Discussion after the episode

In this episode Artur and Hannes do a retrospective on 2017. They share their personal highlights, favorite talks, disapointments, learnings and much more.

Hosts:

  • Artur Dryomov @arturdryomov, personal blog, GitHub
  • Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub

Links:

Talks:

  • Two Stones, One Bird: Implementation Tradeoffs by Christina Lee - KotlinConf 2017
  • Testing Kotlin at Scale: Spek by Artem Zinnatullin - KotlinConf 2017
  • The Reactive Workflow Pattern (Droidcon New York 2017) and Update (Droidcon San Francisco) by Ray Ryan
  • The Resurgence of SQL by Jake Wharton and Alec Strong - Droidcon New York City 2017
  • Embracing SQL Without Abstraction by Alec Strong - Droidcon New York City 2016
  • OpenYOLO: Authentication made easy and secure by Iain McGinniss - Droidcon London 2017 and corresponding blog post

Libraries:

  • Spek
  • Room
  • Lottie
  • Reagent: Experiments for future reactive libraries (by using coroutines)

Programming Languages and Technologies:

  • TypeScript
  • Dart
  • WebOS

Other Links:

  • Book recommendation: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck: A Counterintuitive Approach to Living a Good Life
  • Christina Lee's tweet: "Does it matter to you if speakers have given their talk before?"
  • KotlinConf 2017 App
  • Spans, a Powerful Concept by Flavien Laurent
  • shouldShowRequestPermissionRationale()
  • SharedMemory
  • People to follow: Chris Lattner

item.title: Episode 17: Switching Gears to C# and .NET
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 17: Switching Gears to C# and .NET

How to listen & subscribe

  • Discussion after the episode

In this episode Artur chatted with Dmitry Savchenko about C#, .NET and everything in between.

The reason is simple — we are changing our jobs as Android developers to be real enterprise professionals. Prepare for next episodes about macOS AppKit, Linux kernel, Go microservices and Plan 9 vs. Inferno. And maybe gardening at some point. Also — April Fools!

Seriously though — the episode is a great introduction into C# world. Just for erudition sake, you know.

Guest:

  • Dmitry Savchenko: GitHub

Hosts:

  • Artur Dryomov: @arturdryomov, personal blog, GitHub

Links:

C#

  • Anders Hejlsberg — Turbo Pascal, C# and TypeScript designer
  • Versions history
  • Nullable reference types preview
  • struct
  • async and await
  • yield
  • F#
  • Q#

.NET

  • .NET Framework
  • .NET Core
  • .NET Framework vs. .NET Core

Tools

  • JetBrains ReSharper
  • JetBrains Rider
  • Roslyn — .NET Compiler Platform
  • Visual Studio Code
  • MSBuild
  • NuGet
  • Team Foundation Server

item.title: Episode 19, Part 1: Model-View-Intent
item.itunes:summary:
Episode 19, Part 1: Model-View-Intent with Benoît Quenaudon from Square

How to listen & subscribe

  • Discussion after the episode

In the first part of episode #19 Artur and Hannes chatted with Benoît Quenaudon from Square about Model-View-Intent. We discussed the difference between MVP, MVVM and MVI, how to implement MVI, reusable components and how to test MVI based applications.

Guest:

  • Benoît Quenaudon @artem_zin, personal blog, GitHub

Hosts:

  • Hannes Dorfmann @sockeqwe, personal blog, GitHub
  • Artur Dryomov @arturdryomov, personal blog, GitHub

Links

  • Cycle.js
  • Android Blueprint: ToDo App using MVI by Benoît
  • droidcon NYC 2017 - Model-View-Intent for Android
  • In-App Navigation with Coordinators
  • droidcon SF 2017 - The Reactive Workflow Pattern Update
  • Benoît's Tweet: "We see more and more "reactive" architectures on Android but I think you're doing it wrong if you have a subscribe in your presenter. Ideally, the presenter should be an ObservableTransformer."
